summary: This is a Memorandum Opinion & Order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding a protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The court resolves disputes between the defense and prosecution, ultimately adopting the Government's proposed protective order that restricts Maxwell from publicly referencing alleged victims and witnesses except those who have publicly identified themselves in this litigation, and denies Maxwell's request to restrict potential Government witnesses from using discovery materials.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose defense team sought specific language in a protective order regarding public references to alleged victims/witnesses and restrictions on Government witnesses.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who authored the Memorandum Opinion & Order, ruling on the protective order dispute between the Government and Maxwell's defense.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as a central figure in the case; the protective order dispute involves individuals who have made public statements relating to him or Maxwell.

connections.description: The document references individuals who have spoken publicly about Maxwell or Epstein, indicating their cases are closely related.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and issued this ruling on the protective order.

events.title: Court Issues Protective Order Ruling
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues a Memorandum Opinion & Order adopting the Government's proposed protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

keyFacts: The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request for a broad exception to publicly reference alleged victims or witnesses who had spoken publicly about her or Jeffrey Epstein, limiting such references only to those who have publicly identified themselves in this specific litigation.

The court found the Government demonstrated good cause to protect the privacy of alleged victims and witnesses, even if they had made past public statements, as participating in a criminal prosecution is distinct from making general public statements.

The court rejected Maxwell's unprecedented request to restrict potential Government witnesses and their counsel from using discovery materials for purposes other than preparing for the criminal trial, noting existing legal restrictions on the Government are sufficient.

The protective order allows the defense to reference identities of individuals they believe may be relevant to potential defense witnesses and their counsel during investigation and trial preparation.
